required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Nordic Hamstring and Repeated-sprint Ability in Football (Soccer) Players
clinical_study.official_title: The Efficacy of a 10-week Intervention, Using the Nordic Hamstring Exercise, on Repeated-sprint Ability in Football (Soccer) Players - a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to investigate the efficacy of a 10-week intervention, using the Nordic Hamstring exercise, on repeated-sprint ability in male sub-elite football players. The primary outcome measure is total sprint time during 4x6 sprint of 10 meters measured using dual-beam photoelectric cells. Additionally, eccentric knee flexor strength is measured using the Nordbord hamstring strength measure. The hypothesis is that strength training of the knee flexor muscles elicited by the Nordic Hamstring exercise will result in enhanced repetitive sprint-ability expressed as a decrease in total sprint time. Furthermore, baseline data is used to assess to correlation between eccentric hamstring strength and active hamstring flexibility AND sprint performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Total sprint time measured during 4x6 sprints of 10 meters. The sprints are performed every 15s and the sets are separated by 3 minutes of rest.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured prior to and after the intervention period (at week 0 & 10)

secondary_outcome.measure: Single sprint times (best sprint time, sprint time during last sprint).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured prior to and after the intervention period (at week 0 & 10)

secondary_outcome.measure: Maximal eccentric knee flexor strength measured using Nordbord device
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured prior to and after the intervention period (at week 0 & 10)

secondary_outcome.measure: Eccentric knee flexor strength endurance measured during 12 repetitions of the Nordic Hamstring exercise using Nordbord device.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured prior to and after the intervention period (at week 0 & 10)

secondary_outcome.measure: Active range of motion of hamstring muscles measured using inclinometer.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured prior to and after the intervention period (at week 0 & 10)

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between eccentric hamstring strength and active hamstring flexibility AND sprint performance.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured prior to the intervention (at week 0)

arm_group.description: The Nordic Hamstring group performs a progressive strengthening program (Mjolsnes et al., 2004) comprising of the Nordic Hamstring exercise during a period of 10 weeks. The training load increases from one session per week in week 1 to 3 sessions per week in week 3-10. Number of sets and repetitions progressively increase from 2 to 3 and 5 to 12, respectively. The exercise program is performed in the end of a regular football training session.
The control group are asked not to perform the exercise or any other specific strength training for the hamstring muscles and to continue to play football as usual.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Sub-elite Danish football player
- Age 17-35.
- Able to participate fully in competitive football activities at the time of testing
Exclusion Criteria:
- Hamstring pain resulting in loss of training and matches 2 months prior to study initiation.
- Specific systematic strength training of the hamstring muscles (>1/week) in the preceding 2 months before study initiation.
- Specific systematic sprint training (>1/week) in the preceding 2 months before study initiation.
- Longstanding injury (>6 weeks) in the lower extremities in the preceding 6 months to study initiation.

overall_official.affiliation: Hvidovre University Hospital. University of Southern Denmark

facility.name: Both the intervention and testing included in protocol will be conducted in the facilities of the included football clubs in Copenhagen, Denmark.

reference.citation: Mjølsnes R, Arnason A, Østhagen T, Raastad T, Bahr R. A 10-week randomized trial comparing eccentric vs. concentric hamstring strength training in well-trained soccer players. Scand J Med Sci Sports. 2004 Oct;14(5):311-7.
